turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Mallory, what did you think of Mickey's plan? Did you think it would work?

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: It wasn't 'till we got on the ground floor that I totally realized they weren't gonna shoot unless we shot first. When we got out of the stairwell, I remember thinking, 'Oh my God. This might work.' But Mickey knew it would work all along. There wasn't any doubt in his mind. It's not like there was and he just didn't show it. He knew it would work.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: What did you think then?

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: I wondered how long it would be before we'd get to be alone together. And I wondered if I could wait that long.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Did you have anything to do with the riot in the laundry room?

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Haven't you been listening to a fuckin' word I said? ...Oh, I'm sorry. Can I say fuckin'? I can't, can I?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Try to keep it to a minimum.

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: We had nothing to do with that riot. That riot was just -- whatchmacallit --

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Well, now me and Mickey are gonna take it easy. Just enjoy each other's company, stop and smell the roses, notice the color purple, stuff like that.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: How do you intend to disappear? you're probably the most famous couple in America.

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Well, back in slave times they had a thing called the underground railroad. And we got a whole fan club out there just waiting to be conductors.  So, you kids out there, keep the faith. Cause Mickey and Mallory will be comin' to your town real soon.

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Naw, she don't mind.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Grace. I'd like to talk to you about your murdered brother Tim, if you feel up to it.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Now, when we get out there, you do what we say or it's curtains. If we say move, you move. If we say left, you move left. If we say right, you move right. If we say mole, you dig a hole. Got it?

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Are we in a big hurry?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You got something you want to do?

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: By all means, knock yourself out.

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Thanks. Roll 'em, Donut.

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Mickey!

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Don't stop!

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Hasn't it?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: We still got a few tricks up our sleeves.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Divine intervention.

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: What he said. We didn't know jack shit about and riot. It just happened. It was kismet. We didn't even know those people. How are we supposed to organize a riot when we've been in fuckin' isolation for the past year? Just bleep out the fucks and jack shits.  I mean, it's not like we care. If they wanna say we masterminded the whole thing, let 'em. It won't exactly keep us up at night. But you said you wanted the truth, and the truth is we were just lucky.

turns.speaker: MALLORY
turns.text: Looked like an interview to me.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I said we'd give you an interview. I never said we wouldn't kill you.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Why are Mickey and Mallory being moved to an asylum? And who made the decision?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: The prison board made the decision. A board of which I belong. We're the who. The why is simple. Mickey and Mallory are mentally ill and need to be under a doctor's care, where hopefully they'll receive the help they need.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Mickey and Mallory were deemed competent in a mental examination before their trial. I'm confused. What's changed?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Well, since that time, they've killed one person during their trail. And since their incarceration, they've killed one psychologist along with several guards and inmates.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: When they were found competent before, they had already killed fifty people. Other than the fact they're a disciplinary problem, which frankly shouldn't surprise anyone, I still don't see where this situation is any different then it was before. So, I ask you again, Mr. McClusky, what's changed?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: What's changed, Mr. Gayle, is our minds. We felt they were competent a year ago. A year has passed, sir, a year where they were under close observation, day in and day out, and their behaviour has led us to believe we were wrong.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Who is we?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: The prison board and the doctors who examined them.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Were any of the doctors who made the first evaluation on the Knoxs mental state asked to re-examine them?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Using the same doctors is not common practice.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: I take it by your answer it was a whole new team?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Now that you bring it up, yes. They were different men. I hadn't really thought that much about it. Since many psychiatric opinions are, by a rule, sought out for this kind of situation. What do you think normally happens? The Knoxs are assigned a family psychologist that takes care of them throughout the rest of their lives? The state doesn't work like that.

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Congratulations on the Curtis Fox case, Scagnetti. You put an end to a nightmare. The ladies of this city can get to sleep again, and they have you to thank.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Dewight McClusky of the California Prison Board. Take a seat please.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Who isn't?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: You been followin' the news coverage?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: They've been separated since their incarceration in a couple of penitentiaries---

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Susanville, Soledade.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: They've killed a shitload of inmates and guards---

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Five inmates, eight guards and one psychiatrist all in one year's time... Very good. You do keep up with the headlines.

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Look, our situation in a nutshell is, no prison wants 'em, no prison will take 'em. I'm even talkin' hellholes, where the warden's as hard as a bar of iron. No one wants those fuckin' assholes behind their walls, dealin' with 'em day in, day out.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: I can appreciate that.

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: So can we. So the solution to our little problem is we had them deemed crazy. And we're shippin' 'em to Nystrom Asylum for the criminally insane.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Lobotomy Bay?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: You've heard of it?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: So, how do I fit into this scheme?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: The public loves you Jack...You don't mind if I call you Jack, do you?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: By all means.

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: You're a celebrated cop. Twenty-six years on the force, a best-seller out on paperback...

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: You're a breathing icon of justice and that's why you were chosen to deliver Mr. and Mrs. Knox. We, the prison board we, knows that once you get them on the road if anything should happen, an escape attempt, an accident, fire, anything...Jack 'Supercop' Scagnetti would be there to look out for his public's best interests.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: You write the script Jack, call it, 'Showdown in Mojave: The extermination of Mickey and Mallory', whatever... Have we found our man?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Who's the song bird?

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Mickey's better half herself. Mallory Knox. This little lady drowned her father in a fish tank.

turns.speaker: MCCLUSKY
turns.text: Because they wouldn't give them their blessing for marriage.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Ain't love grand.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ...one night I was asleep, and a noise wakes me up. I thought, 'Oh shit, somebody's broken in.' I didn't own a gun, so I go into the living room with a fucking umbrella. Okay, it turned out to be nothing. God made the noise. Who knows?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: How's it goin'?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Looks like we got a Mexican standoff.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Slide the shotgun over here, put your hands behind your head, put your forehead on the floor.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Or what? You'll wound me? I can blow you in half and you know it.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: I've never wounded anything in my life. I got you locked right between the eyes.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Did you ever see 'Eldorado?'

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Okay, buddy boy, where ya keepin' Mallory? I know she's still here, and I know you know where. So, start talking or my first work as a director will be your death scene.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: She's in the holding cell, on this floor.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You're taking us to that holding cell now.  All right, Cut!

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Okay, Wayne, step forward.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: How come you never talk?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: She was born without a tongue.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Oh my God!  Sorry.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Say something.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Anything.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Ah...fine. Let me make an adjustment here, and we'll be ready to rock 'n roll. Oh...uh, the dumbass at the donut place put a chocolate cream filled I asked for in your box.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: There's a chocolate cream filled in there?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Yeah. Ya see, I ordered that special.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Tough titty, it's mine now.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Look, I'll trade you.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You guys stay on your bellies.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: How is it?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Not good.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Do you have a back up.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: It's video.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Even better. Wayne call your station, tell 'em we're going live a little early today. Make it happen!

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You ready, Donut?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Ready.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Wagons, hooaaa!

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Hello Mickey. We've never been introduced, but I'm Wayne Gayle. I don't know if you've ever heard of me or remember me. I was one of the reporters outside the courthouse during your trial---

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Everybody knows who you are. You're famous.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: The episode we did on Mickey and Mallory was one of our most popular ones.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Did you ever do one on Wayne Gacy?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Whose ratings were higher?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Yours.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: How 'bout Ted Bundy? Ever do one on him?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Yes. Yours got the larger Nielson share.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Good...yuppie piece of shit.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: What I'd like to do---

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: How 'bout Manson?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Manson beat you.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty hard to beat the king.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: We've been waiting to do a follow up episode on you for a long time. And that time has definitely come.  I feel it's apparent to anyone who's hip to what's going on that the prison board has thrown the constitution straight out the fuckin' window. You and Mallory may be killers, but you're not insane. You belong in a prison, not in an asylum. The prison board is blatantly railroading you into a hospital for the sole purpose of turning you into vegetables. Now some people are saying, 'So what?' I am not one of those people. If we avert our eyes while they do this to you, we give them permission to do it again whenever they see fit. Today they wipe clean your mind because they feel your actions are dangerous, tomorrow they wipe clean my mind because they feel what I say is dangerous. Where does it all stop?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: My problem Mickey, is that you don't exactly inspire empathy. I'm all alone on this. I need your help. I want what the prison board is doing to be the focus of our follow up episode. Now I have interviews with chairman of the prison board Dewight McClusky about this issue. And I'm tellin' ya, Mickey, he looks bad. The two psychologists they used for their psychiatric kangaroo court won't talk to us, which always looks bad. I have an interview with both the judge of your trial, Bert Steinsma, and the psychologist and author, Emil Reinghold, both of which discount the notion that you're insane. You put that all together, and what the state is doing becomes obvious. But the network isn't satisfied. They feel the show needs another element. It needs you. In order to put the show on the air, I need to get an interview with you. You haven't talked to the press since your trial. Now, a few days before you get transferred to an asylum, you grant an interview on television with Wayne Gayle. We're talkin' a media event here. Every son of a bitch out the with a TV set's gonna tune in to see that. We'll make their motives so blatant, we'll shame 'em into dropping the whole thing. At least for a little while, the publicity would keep them from just giving you and Mallory lobotomies. Well, whatta ya say?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Have you talked to Mallory about this?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: She won't even see me, Mickey. Now you're not supposed to know anything about what's going on with her, but I'm gonna tell ya somethin'. Since you two've been sentenced, Mallory hasn't spoken one word.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: She doesn't talk?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Not to anybody. She sings.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: She sings? What does she sing?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Songs. 'He's A Rebel', 'Leader Of The Pack', 'Town Without Pity', that Dusty Springfield song 'I Only Want To Be With You'. That's what I hear anyway. Her behaviour was the main thing the doctors' report used against you. So even if she would see me, which she won't, I couldn't put her on camera anyway. If I ask her, 'Mallory, are you insane?' And she starts singing 'Dead Skunk In The Middle Of The Road', that blows our whole case.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Mickey, how do you feel about cross- examining Grace Mulberry?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I'm keen with anticipation.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Okay now, before we get started here, there's a few things we have to get clear about.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: All right, Mickey.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Let's discuss it when I'm unbound.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Sorry about that.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Don't worry about it.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: We're about ready to go here. Are you ready?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Let's do it.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: So, Mickey, tell us what you do for fun.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Aside from the obvious?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Much obliged. What do I do for fun? Do you want to know what I do for fun or what I did for fun?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: What? Oh, aaahhh, what you did for fun for starters.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What I did for fun for starters.  Well, something I used to do...always was a lot of fun...  No, scratch that. Let me think of something else. In fact, why don't we come back to that question. Ask me something else.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Do you miss Mallory?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Of course, I miss Mallory. She's my wife. I haven't seen her in a long time. What a stupid question.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Then was it worth it?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Was what worth it?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Was massacring all those people worth being separated from your wife for the rest of your life?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Do you think up these questions or the girl with no tongue?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: No, Mickey, I can't let you get away with that shit. Answer the question. Was it worth it? You haven't seen, heard, or smelled Mallory in a year. Was it worth it?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Was an instant of purity worth a lifetime lie? Yeah, it was.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Excuse me, did you say an instant of purity? What was the instant of purity? The bodies you left behind on your bloody trail?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: That's only part of it. I mean, it's a big, big, big part. But it's only the chorus, it's not the whole song.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Please explain to me, Mickey, where's the purity that you couldn't live without in five year old Danny Millhouse's blown off head? Where's the purity in forty-eight people who are no longer on this planet because they met you and Mallory? What's so fucking pure about that?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: You just said an instant of purity was preferrable to a lifetime lie. I don't understand. What's so pure about forty-eight dead bodies?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You'll never understand. Me and you, Wayne, we're not even the same species. I used to be you...then I evolved. From where you're standing, you're a man. From where I'm standing, you're a ape. I'm here...I'm right here... and you...you're somewhere else, man. You say why? I say why not?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Tell me about the purity.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: It's not that easy, Wayne. Donuts and a smoke only get you so far. You're gonna have to do your job.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Okay...okay...I'll buy that. We'll move on and come back later.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I'm sure we will.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Describe Mallory.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Describe Mallory? Okay. She's pretty, she's got blonde hair, two eyes, two feet, two hands, ten fingers...

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Don't play dumb with me, Mickey. You know what I mean. Describe Mallory.  What's up here?  What's in here?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: That's indescribable.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Well, riddle me this, Batman. How do you feel about the fact that you're never gonna see Mallory again?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Says who?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Says the United States of America.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: When have they ever been right?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Everybody thought I'd gone crazy. The cops, my mom, everybody. But you see, they all missed the point of the story. I wasn't crazy. But when I was holding the shotgun, it all became clear. I realized for the first time my one true calling in life. I'm a natural born killer.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Okay, let's cut it.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I could go for a Coke.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Could I get a Coke for Mickey?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You guys wanna hear a joke I heard?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Now, I'm no comedian, but it's pretty funny. It's a Little Johnny joke. Now in the joke, Little Johnny can't talk. And Little Johnny's teenage sister asks her mother if she can go out on a date.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Donut, get your camera. See if it's broke.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Let me check on Scott. He's hurt bad.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Scott's dead. And unless you wanna play follow the leader, shut up and do as you're told.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Okay, we're going out that door, and we're gonna march down the hall and right out of the building.  Donut said something about a news van.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Yeah, we have a van.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Where's it parked?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Out front.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Let me have the keys.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Mickey, can I talk to you alone?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: This is crazy. You can't escape like this.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Probably not, but we're gonna give it the old college try.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: We'll all be killed.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: That's what I thought. You tell them that. When we go down those stairs, I want you to scream what you just told me. 'My name is Wayne Gayle! I am the star of American Maniacs watched every week by'-- how many people?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: On average forty million.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: 'Every week by forty million people. I am a respected journalist.' Have you won any awards?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Are you kidding? The Golden Globe, The Edward R. Murrow award...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: 'Respected journalist'-- On your knees...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ...'Winner of the Golden Globe and the Edward R. Murrow award among others.' Tell 'em the name of your personal lawyer, his firm, his address, and phone number. Tell 'em about the mayor and the unemployment lines. You getting the idea?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Say it. Scream it. All the way out the front door and into your van. And if you stop screaming, I swear to God I'll blow your head off.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Got it.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: We ain't got all fuckin' day!

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Without any further ado, Mickey and Mallory...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: C'mon, c'mon, let's hurry this up.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: So, what now?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Just wait one fucking minute.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I said I'd give you a interview. Now unless I'm mistaken, we just did a interview.  We did an interview, didn't we?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: ...developed between the three of us. We're kindda in this together, don't ya think?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: No. Not really.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Don't touch those triggers! Please. I think I've already proven that a live Wayne Gayle is much more better that a dead...Way-- Gayle. I was your passport out of jail, not Duncan Homolka. But me! I'll be your passport outta---

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Just save your breath, Wayne. We hate you. If anybody in the fuckin' world deserves to die, it's you.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Wait! You can't kill me. Mickey and Mallory always leave somebody alive to tell the tale.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: We are.  Your camera.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Let's make a little music, Colorada.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: NO!!!

turns.speaker: MOVIE MALLORY
turns.text: I can't go. I'm too fucked up.

turns.speaker: MOVIE MICKEY
turns.text: I'm not saying it's not gonna hurt, but--

turns.speaker: MOVIE MALLORY
turns.text: I can't run with you, Mickey! I really want to. If I could, I would, but I can't. I gotta stay here. But you can still get out of here.

turns.speaker: MOVIE MICKEY
turns.text: No fuckin' way! No fuckin' way!

turns.speaker: MOVIE MALLORY
turns.text: If they stay, they'll catch you, and they don't have to catch you---

turns.speaker: MOVIE MICKEY
turns.text: No fuckin' way!

turns.speaker: MOVIE MALLORY
turns.text: Mickey, you're wasting time!

turns.speaker: MOVIE MICKEY
turns.text: I don't give a damn if a million United States marines, all whistling the halls of Montezuma, are gonna come marchin' down this alley any second. There ain't not fuckin' way in hell I'm leaving you. And that's that!

turns.speaker: MOVIE MICKEY
turns.text: Yeah baby.

turns.speaker: MOVIE MALLORY
turns.text: You made every day like kindergarten.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Then you've seen the scene where Arnold Schwartzenegger is talking to Lou Ferigno.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: How can you say that you 'admire' them?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: It's like this, Wayne. Two people are standing in a dark room waiting for the other to attack. These two people can't see each other, yet they know they're there. Now, they can either stand in the dark room forever waiting until they die of boredom, or one of them can make the first move.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Why can't they just shake hands and be friends?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: They can't because neither knows if the other is a deranged senseless killer like the Knoxs. So, you may as well make the first move.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: And they made the first move?

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Unfortunately, yes.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: I admire them.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I do, too.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Hypnotizing.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Have you seen 'Pumping Iron?'

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Through the power of the simple word---

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: And a snake-eye glare.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: ---and a snake-eye glare, Arnold was able to totally psyche out any confidence Ferigno had.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: He squashed him mentally before physically defeating him.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: He had the edge. The mind's edge.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Mickey and Mallory have that edge.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Only on a much grander scale.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: They've hypnotized the nation.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Schwartzenegger was the king of the edge before they came along.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: That's the Mickey and Mallory way.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: That's the way of the world.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: They're shocking the world into remembering the primal law.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Survival of the fittest.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: They had us tied down during one of their house raids, you've seen the headlines, and they were taking a chainsaw to our legs before they were gonna kill us.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Just for fun, I guess.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: And then Mallory stops Mickey and says, 'Hey, these are the Brothers Hun.'

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Mickey stops sawin' on my leg and says, 'Oh my God, I'm your biggest fan!'

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Apparently, they've seen all our films.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: They were especially influenced by 'Conquering Huns of Neptune.'

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: So, Mallory calls 911 and they took off.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: They actually apologized.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: I want two men stationed in that tier, and I want men with rifles all along the walkway.

turns.speaker: PITNEY
turns.text: Capt'n!

turns.speaker: PITNEY
turns.text: Here's the layout of the laundry room.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Where do the air ducts lead?

turns.speaker: PITNEY
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: What do you think, Pitney? How much Explosives do you think that they really have in there?

turns.speaker: PITNEY
turns.text: It's hard to say Capt'n.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Take a wild stab!

turns.speaker: PITNEY
turns.text: I'll say enough to destroy this wing.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: The entire wing?

turns.speaker: PITNEY
turns.text: That's my opinion.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Jesus...

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Drink up! This is a celebration. This is the day we received word we were gonna make television history. We're gonna have the first sit down, in depth interview with the most charismatic serial killer ever, one day before he's being shipped to a mental hospital for the rest of his life. This is one of those golden moments that happens maybe only four times in a lucky journalist's career. This is Wallace with Noriega, this is Elton John confessing his bi-sexuality to the Rolling Stone, this is the tearful reporting of the Hindenberg disaster, this is Truffaut setting the record straight on Hitchcock, this is a Robert Capa photo, this is Woodward and Bernstien meeting Deep Throat in an underground parking lot, this is John Reid reporting 'The Ten Days That Shook The World', this is the hippies' bloody palms at Kent State, the Maysles brothers at Altamont, this is the Nixon/Frost interviews...

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: This is Raymond Burr witnessing the destruction of Tokyo by Godzilla.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: How immediate is immediately?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Next week's episode.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Now we got to film a new intro for the follow up episode. But we put the intro for the first episode at the beginning temporarily so you can see it with some scope.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: I hear ya. Play.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: You can't be serious?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: I'm as serious about that as I am about going back to the donut store, and dipping that stupid Mexican's head into the batter for forgetting my chocolate cream filled. Gimme that other box.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Huh uh. This dozen is for Mickey.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: That dumbass probably put my chocolate cream filled in there by mistake.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Roger, no.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: What's the big deal? Take out my chocolate cream filled, put one of these roasted coconut---

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Roger, do you understand what the word 'no' means? It's important we establish a rapport. Something as simple as a dozen donuts can mean the world to somebody who hasn't had a donut in a year.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: So you're giving a man who butchers whole families, little babies included, my chocolate cream filled?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Okay, guys, we're here. L.A. County Jail. Julie, just park in the front.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Wayne---

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Roger, I'm starting to get pissed. Just drop this fuckin' donut shit, and gather your gear.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Roger, enough with the fucking donuts! What did I tell you. Stop bothering Mickey, and get behind your nagra.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Fine. Roger, what the hell are you doing? You're bothering the serial killer.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Roger?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Rockin'!

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Scotty?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Pleased to meet ya, Jack. I read your book. I'm impressed. Good work on Curtis Fox.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: What's the travelling arrangements?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Well, Mickey and Mallory can't be together. So, we'll put you on one of our prison busses and you'll take Mallory first, then you'll come back for Mickey.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: And where do you keep Mickey?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: We got his stinkin' ass in the deepest, darkest cell in the whole place. But it just so happens that right now he's got a special visitor.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Wayne Gayle.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Wayne Gayle!

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: What the hell happened to you?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: You should see the other bitch. What time you got?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Two-thirty. Shhh...

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Are you all set?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Yeah. Bus is all gassed up and ready to roll.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: I assigned you Bingham and Washington to go along.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Yeah, we met. They're good men.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: They're real Goddamn good. They'll be there for when ya need 'em. Where are they?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Waitin' in the lounge.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: How 'bout Mallory?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Coolin' her jets in a holding cell.

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Nothing for me. I'm leavin'.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Me, neither. I don't eat meat.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Jack, could you stay up here for a while?

turns.speaker: SCAGNETTI
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: I'm taking one of these men. Yates, come with me.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: We got tonight and tomorrow to get our shit together. The day after that they're shippin' Mallory. That's when we do the Mickey Knox interview, 'cause the next day he goes.

turns.speaker: SCOTT
turns.text: Would the network really not run it without the interview?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Are you kidding? The last thing they expected was Mickey Knox to get up close and personal. They wanted a follow up episode and would've taken anything I had given them. I'm not gonna tell Mickey Knox that. I'm gonna make him think his grey matter depends on it. When I told Woody and the brass about this coup, they practically shit a brick. I'm talkin' an adobe brick. They want to expand the show to a hour, and they want it on immediately.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: So Unruly Julie's comin' with me and planning the interview.  You two go down to the editing bay, take the old footage and the new footage, put it together, and see what we got. Get it into shape so when we finish the interview, we can just stick it in.

turns.speaker: SCOTT
turns.text: When do you want the assembly?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Tomorrow.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Okay, boys, let's have it.

turns.speaker: SCOTT
turns.text: Well, basically, what we did was put part of the old show on first...

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Good work, my brothers. Fan-fuckin'- tastic! I think that interview stuff's too long, we can lose some of that. Keep the girls, keep the long hairs, keep the Hun brothers, keep the black guy, keep the movie shit, and keep the cop at the donut shop. Lose the rest. And cut the interview with the prison board fellow before that. Cut it after I ask, 'I take it by your answer it was a whole new team.' Don't even let him answer. Fuck him. Then cut to me talking about the two chicken shit psychiatrists and straight in Dr. Reinghold laughing.

turns.speaker: SCOTT
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: How's it working, Scotty?

turns.speaker: SCOTT
turns.text: Perfecto!

turns.speaker: SCOTT
turns.text: Rollin'...and speed!

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Slate it.

turns.speaker: SCOTT
turns.text: Camera jam! I'm sorry Wayne. God.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Fucking dammit! Mickey hold onto that thought. Reload, quick!

turns.speaker: SCOTT
turns.text: It's gonna be beautiful.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Super cool.  This is great stuff. How ya doin'?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: But how can you say that?

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: They're mesmerising.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: But you see, that's okay, Wayne.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: They passed the 'edge' along to us.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: How so?

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: By taking away our legs. Now we have to fight harder to get ahead than anyone else you'll find in this gym. Probably the whole city. They gave us the fighting spirit. Before this happened I was content. Now I'm pissed off. Now I'm half a man and I've got to work like the devil to get whole again.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: But you'll never be whole again.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Never is a very long time, Wayne. A word only the weak use. I'm not a sore loser. Even if I don't have a leg to stand on, I'm going to get up and fight this world until I'm on top again.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Hello, Mr. Gayle. I'm Phil Wurlitzer. We talked on the phone. It's a pleasure to meet you.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Same here. Let me introduce my crew. Scott...Roger...and Unruly Julie ...this is...I'm sorry. What's your title again?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: I'm the superintendent here at L.A. County Jail. Me and my deputies are who you'll be working with while you're here.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: That sounds great. Look, I don't want any of this to intimidate you. This is not going to be a big deal. This is going to be very easy.  I need to talk with Mr. Wurlitzer. You guys get your equipment ready, power up the van and confirm a transmission code for the remote. Julie come with me.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: How's everything coming, Mr. Gayle?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Everything's coming along just fine. Phil, I wanted to know if I could have a small word with you.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: By all means.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: You met the kids I have working for me? Great bunch, aren't they?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Oh yes, indeed. Top flight.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Scott, genius cameraman, Roger, magician with sound. Unruly Julie, I could sooner do without my arm than Unruly Julie.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Is that her real name?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Just a little nickname. Yep, they're my kids and they're all I need. After working together these past coupla years, we're like well-oiled machinery. No, more like a Formula race car. No, scratch that one, too. What we're really like is a Swiss watch. Small, intricate, compact...it shouldn't work as well as it does, but it does. Because of the craftsmanship, the expertise, and the artist's loving hand.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Now, Phil, I don't know if you've ever been on a set before---

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Ya know, I was.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: I was on the 'Dukes of Hazzard' set about eight years ago.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Well...small world. Well, then, you know firsthand how Hollywood does things. Lights all over the place, generators, a hundred and fifty crew members---

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Oh, that 'Dukes of Hazzard' show, there was probably ninety-five people there, maybe more.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: See what I mean? It's a funny business, isn't it?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: It sure is.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: They got a asshole over here.  A asshole sitting down reading a magazine over there.  A asshole perched up there.  Assholes everywhere. Hey, maybe if we were doin' that kiss, kiss, bang, bang stuff we'd need all those assholes, too. What we're about is intimacy. We're about two people having a conversation. Say I was interviewing you. All I want you to worry about is what I ask you. I want a trust to develop. If you're thinking about all this...  ...you're not going to relax, a trust won't develop, we'll be talking a each other instead of to each other, there will be no chance for intimacy.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Well, just what the hell do you expect me to do?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Lose 'em.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Mr. Gayle, do you have the slightest idea how dangerous Knox is?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Mr. Wurlitzer, I assure you, I am very familiar with Mickey Knox's career.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Since he and his wife have been in custody, they've killed---

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Don't recite the fact to me. I'm sure I know 'em better than you do.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Well, let me let you in on one more fact you obviously don't know. If I were to take my men away, Mickey Knox would snap your neck like a twig.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: One...I can take care of myself. I grew up in a tough neighbourhood, and I've handled some pretty rough customers in my day. Mickey Knox doesn't scare me. Two...I'm a journalist, and I'm prepared to take that risk. Three...it ain't gonna happen. Believe me when I tell you, it is in Mickey Knox's own best interest to play this game according to Hoyle.  Wait a minute. We've gotten into a advisory relationship here, which is not what I want.  But seriously, Phil, look at this.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: We got one...two...three...four ...five...six...seven...eight. I mean Jesus Christ, Phil, that's too much. Let's lose some of these guys.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Wayne, if it was anybody else---

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Phil, I'm just scared he's gonna clam up on me with all these sheriffs all over the place. They hate him. He hates them. What kinda intimacy am I gonna create with all this hate in the air. Even you and I feel it.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: What are we talking about?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Two guys?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Okay. I'll take two guys off.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: No, no, no, no, no, no, I mean only two guys.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: I can't do that. Five guys.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Three.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: I'll cut it in half. Four guys, but that's it.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: So we got a deal. Four deputies---

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: And me.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Why don't we make it three deputies and you?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Why don't I have Mickey thrown back into his cell and we can forget the whole thing?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Chill out, Phill. Four deputies and you, I can live with that. We're about ready to go here, so let's get rid of these other assholes.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Don't call my men assholes.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: I didn't mean they were assholes. I mean if they're leaving, get 'em outta here.

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: I'm not running out and getting that piece of shit a Coke.

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Fine.  Julie, why don't you make a food run?  What's around here?

turns.speaker: WAYNE
turns.text: Could we go with you and film it?

turns.speaker: WURLITZER
turns.text: Stay up here and finish your interview, I've got to see what the hell's going on down there before I can take responsibility for you to film there.

turns.speaker: DUFF
turns.text: How 'bout that furniture plant?

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Man, the darkest thing they got in there is Coca-Cola.

turns.speaker: DUFF
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Now, if you want to work like a real nigger, you can always go out and chop cotton.

turns.speaker: DUFF
turns.text: They done that too long in my family.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: They pay you three bucks a day an' all the cotton you can eat.

turns.speaker: DUFF
turns.text: Give her a beer.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: Thanks, Duff. You' a nice guy. Not like Frankie.
